posts.name:
Joe Heikkinen
Joe Heikkinen
posts.content:
Over my career as a sales leader, there is one moment in time that really stands out around sales and marketing alignment. How did we get there?

1. We Got in the Same Room, Regularly:
We met often, face-to-face, to discuss what’s working and what’s not. We were respectful, transparent and honest. We took the iron sharpens iron approach in our meetings. Was there friction, YES! Did we come out of those meetings aligned, YES!

2. We Stopped the Blame Game:
We had common goals and were rowing in the same direction to achieve those goals. We owned the revenue number together with shared incentives and accountability.

3. We Walked a Mile in Each Other's Shoes:
Marketing attended sales calls; sales reviewed marketing content early in the development process.

5. We Fixed the Feedback Loop:
Sales gave timely feedback, and marketing adjusted strategy accordingly. A CRM helped but we were careful that it didn't replace face to face feedback opportunities.

6. We Ditched the Jargon and Got Real:
We focused on what the customer cared about, not internal terminology.

7. We Made Data Useful, Not Just Pretty:
We used data to make decisions, not just fill reports. We aligned on key data and reports and relentlessly fought against REPORT CREEP!

8. We Celebrated Wins Together:
We had a mechanism in place to recognize each other's contributions to success. Every team member could celebrate another. This one is extremely important.

Fixing misalignment takes action, not talk. What’s worked for you? Any tools or processes you've used? Share your thoughts!
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Building strong cross-team relationships is key. Shared goals and open communication really drive success. What tools did you find most effective?

posts.name:
Luigi LENGUITO
Luigi LENGUITO
posts.content:
Today 
#CyberTalent spotlight is on Annie Audic

What was your original career path and how did you end up in the cyber security field?

I started my career in Paris at L’Oréal as a researcher in chemistry and then worked in the photobiology department to study the oxidative stress on DNA caused by sunlight. My position also involved international publications and patents. In the pharmaceutical industry, I became R&D Project Director at Jouveinal, then I worked in business development with the teams Sigmatau (Italy), UCB (Belgium), Nippon Shinyaku (Japan), Jouveinal INC (Canada). Then I was the director of a Regional Center for Innovation and Technology Transfer in the field of health and biotechnology in Rennes, Brittany, and led an ecosystem of 70 research units and 150 companies.

In 2006, I joined the Brittany Region to develop and implement the higher education, research and innovation policy within the general management of the economy, and to manage and supervise the research, innovation and Europe departments. The most significant focus marked the implementation of programs dedicated to satellite technologies and uses, which have been a biotechnologies growth lever for Brittany. In 2014, the President of the region entrusted me with the mission of setting up a Cyber Security Center of Excellence with the Ministry of Defense, and it was created in 2018. From the outset, we have worked on our ecosystem at the regional, national, and European levels.

ℹ️ What is the most appealing thing to you about working in cyber security?

The novelty, a market to create, driving innovation in a constrained, complex world, the need to work on knowledge (research), education (training and behaviour), and the economy at the same time at the three levels: regional, national, and European.

 Name a book/movie that has inspired you. Anything specific to cyber security that you would recommend?

Two books that have nothing to do with each other but that speak of other worlds, that of the androids and the pirates!

Philippe K. DICK, “Do androids dream of electric sheep?”

Bernard SIMIOT, “Ces messieurs de ST Malo


 I recommend you to follow her , like and comment on this post to share her example, and perhaps suggest others to showcase !

>>> This profile is part of a series I’m publishing every other day in collaboration with @Women4Cyber Foundation, follow me to receive the next updates.

comments.commentText:
Luigi LENGUITO very good choice indeed!
 Well deserved Annie! I do remember first time we met 4 years ago during Forum InCyber in Lille on Region Bretagne booth, I was starting my new job as executive coach and you kindly introduced me to CEO’s of Cyber Security startup.
Always a pleasure to met and discuss during FIC or European Cyber Week in Rennes

posts.commentAdded: Inspiring journey, Annie! Your transition from R&D to cyber security showcases the power of diverse experiences driving innovation. #CyberTalent

posts.name:
Snehal Talati
Snehal Talati
posts.content:
What’s with all the buzz about DeepSeek R1 achieving incredible results at a fraction of the cost?

Is it surprising? Not really. We’ve seen this before. India and China have mastered the art of doing more with less.  From ISRO’s Mars mission (at just 1/10th the cost!) to platforms like UPI, they’ve proven time and again that cost-efficiency and innovation go hand in hand.

Meanwhile, in the West, innovation tends to come with a hefty price tag —high labor costs, expensive materials, pristine infrastructure. But here’s the exciting part: the future of AI isn’t just for the big spenders.

Asput it, teams around the world will “run the DOGE for AI” —embracing scrappy, distributed, and imperfect infrastructure to build incredible things. This isn’t cutting corners; it’s creative problem-solving and smart optimization.

DeepSeek R1 is a perfect example of this trend—and it’s exciting to think about what it signals for the democratization of AI. 

What’s your take? Have you seen examples of resourceful innovation in your region or industry? Let’s start the conversation.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! This trend of resourceful innovation is inspiring. Cant wait to see how DeepSeek R1 shapes the future of accessible AI!

posts.name:
Manuj Aggarwal
Manuj Aggarwal
posts.content:
From the Ottoman Empire to AI Empires: Lessons from Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque  

Stepping into the Topkapi Palace and Blue Mosque felt like traveling back in time.

Centuries ago, the Sultan ruled over an empire from these very walls.

As I walked through the marble corridors and stood under the stunning domes,

I couldn’t help but think about how the Ottoman Empire thrived on strategic thinking, adaptation, and a deep understanding of their resources.

Whether in architecture, military strategy, or governance.

And that got me thinking... isn’t AI the Topkapi Palace of our era?

Back then, power was about land, armies, and trade routes.

Today, it’s about data and technology shaping our future.

The Sultan had advisors; we have AI systems.

Are we leveraging AI to grow our “empires” or getting lost in its complexity?

History shows that empires rise and fall based on how they adapt to change.

The Ottomans embraced new tools and alliances when necessary.

Similarly, businesses today that don’t embrace AI will likely be left behind.

Let’s draw inspiration from these monuments and apply their timeless principles to our actions.

Have you visited a place that sparked a surprising connection to today’s world?

I’d love to hear about it!

Drop your thoughts below
posts.commentAdded: What a fascinating perspective! The parallels between historical empires and todays AI landscape are striking. Embracing change is key to thriving!

posts.name:
Neil Sarkar
Neil Sarkar
posts.content:
Let’s start with a simple truth: If you’re still relying on traditional lead scoring methods, you might as well hand your sales team a dartboard and call it strategy.

In a video I just shared, I break down exactly why lead scoring as we know it is outdated, ineffective, and frankly, a waste of time. But don’t worry, it’s not all doom and gloom—I’ve got solutions too.

Why Lead Scoring is Failing You:
️ Outdated Methods – Scoring based on job title or company size? That’s so 1999.
️ No Intent – Leads ignoring your emails shouldn’t score high. Period.
️ Zero Personalization – One-size-fits-all scoring doesn’t work anymore.
️ Data Overload – Tons of data, but no real insights.

So, What’s the Fix?
It’s not magic—it’s AI.
At, we’ve built AI agents that integrate seamlessly with Salesforce to take the guesswork out of lead scoring. They prioritize intent, personalize the process, and analyze behaviors to ensure your team focuses on leads that actually close.

TAKEAWAY:
Traditional lead scoring is broken. Let’s fix it.
Watch the video to see how you can stop chasing dead ends and start converting with confidence. Got questions or horror stories about outdated systems? Drop them in the comments—let’s fix this together.
And remember: Guessing doesn’t close deals, systems do.
posts.commentAdded: Exciting insights! Traditional methods are indeed outdated. AI could be the game-changer we need for effective lead scoring! Looking forward to watching.

posts.name:
Chris Daigle
Chris Daigle
posts.content:
Voice interaction with AI is a game-changer...

And business professionals need to understand this.

Because when you communicate with AI using voice, you get more precise results.

And that precision is invaluable.

Because when you use voice:

→ You save time on typing
→ You get faster responses
→ You minimize errors

That’s why experimenting with different AI tools is crucial.

It’s not just about using one tool.

→ Mix voice interaction with tools like VNote AI
→ Use Grammarly for error-free communication
→ Leverage ChatGPT for complex queries

Finding the right balance between structure and flexibility is key.

And AI can help you achieve that balance.

→ Break tasks into manageable chunks
→ Use visual organizers like whiteboards
→ Let AI organize and refine your thoughts

Personalized conversations and learning with AI can transform your business.

It’s not just about managing tasks.

→ AI offers adaptive learning
→ It provides personalized interactions
→ It helps you overcome communication hurdles

Stay patient and persistent as you adapt.

Change takes time.

→ Expect confusion at first
→ Don’t be surprised by miscommunication
→ Embrace the learning curve

Successful AI usage requires persistence.

And those who succeed have stories to tell.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing voice interaction with AI not only enhances efficiency but also opens up new avenues for creativity in communication. Exciting times ahead!

posts.name:
Mando Sallavanti III, CFP®, CEPA
Mando Sallavanti III, CFP®, CEPA
posts.content:
1,511 days ago, I started my financial planning practice during a global pandemic.

In 2024, I led my firm in financial planning.

But this isn’t a “how-to” success story.

Because that would minimize the brutal reality of building a practice during unprecedented times.

It only cost me:

— Starting from zero during lockdowns
— Countless Zoom calls where prospects ghosted
— Learning to build trust through a screen
— Watching my savings dwindle month after month
— Explaining to family why I chose THIS moment to start

And never knowing if I was making the right call.

This post is for every advisor out there still in the “question everything” phase.

Keep going — The clarity will come.

You’re building something real.

comments.commentText:
Mando Sallavanti III, CFP®, CEPA I remember the early grind well, man! Congrats on thriving through the first few years. . . That’s a massive step, and one that most people never get to.

I have a little bit of a different perspective for you. . . You may have actually stumbled into the best situation possible by starting in 2021. Here’s the deal. . . the financial services business is notoriously slow to evolve and implement technology, so for a long time they made it difficult to do business online. My company started doing all our business online in 2014 and it was brutal because the companies didn’t know how, but the pandemic accelerated this out of necessity. Not only that, but building your business utilizing technology and social media and doing meetings primarily through video conferencing rather than in person meetings is a far more efficient and effective way to build a practice/business.

posts.commentAdded: Inspiring journey! Your resilience during tough times is a true testament to your dedication. Keep pushing through—clarity awaits! 🌟

posts.name:
Khwaja Shaik
Khwaja Shaik
posts.content:
AI Governance Insight: Board Leadership in the AI Age 

Asrightly emphasizes, understanding the nuanced landscape of AI models and the importance of Open Source AI are crucial for strategic decision-making. I counsel Board Chairs and lead directors to go beyond surface-level engagement to truly drive competitive advantage.

Key Technology Imperatives I have been engaging on Board's AI Oversight:

• Agentic AI: Move beyond text generation. Seek AI capabilities that can take meaningful actions, creating genuine competitive differentiation.

• Risk Governance: AI safety isn't just a tech issue—it's a critical board-level risk management responsibility. Embrace robust red-teaming and safety testing metrics.

• Strategic Vision: Cultivate a boardroom culture of trend-spotting and strategic sense-making. Align AI initiatives with business goals and market dynamics.

Critical AI Governance Checklist:
 Explore all strategic AI options (Closed vs. Open Source LLMs)
 Ensure digital and cyber literacy at the board level
 Prioritize governance, organizational design, and technological capabilities
 Drive responsible growth through informed digital transformation

The differentiator? A digitally-savvy board director who can navigate complex technological landscapes and guide senior management towards transformative AI strategies.

comments.commentText: These connections between agentic AI and the critical role of board-level risk management are invaluable. As someone deeply involved in digital transformation, I appreciate you outlining the essential steps for boards to drive meaningful AI adoption. Excellent resource!

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! A digitally-savvy board is vital for navigating AIs complexities and driving informed strategic decisions.

posts.name:
Cindy Rayfield
Cindy Rayfield
posts.content:
